column4: Franklin Templeton grabs more Gulf government debt amid oil crash
column5: DUBAI (Reuters) - Franklin Templeton has recently bought more bonds issued by governments in the Gulf, including high-yield names like Oman and Bahrain, seeing value as yields spiked on the back of plunging oil prices and the coronavirus outbreak.
column6: Gulf governments are raising billions of dollars in the debt markets to offset the impact of lower oil revenue on their budgets, but a recent sell-off due to plunging oil and the coronavirus pandemic has pushed up their borrowing costs.
column7: Abu Dhabi and Qatar sold $17 billion in bonds between them last week and Saudi Arabia is expected to close a multi-billion dollar issue later on Wednesday.
column8: Since the beginning of March, Franklin Templeton’s GCC Bond Fund increased exposure to sovereigns to 39% from 29% and slashed financial institutions to 12% from 19%, Dino Kronfol, Franklin Templeton’s chief investment officer of global sukuk and MENA fixed income, told Reuters.
column9: The investment firm, which managed about $580 billion in global assets as of end-March according to its website, cut exposure to Gulf government-related entities to 18% from 20% and edged up corporates to 27% from 25.5% in the same period.
column10: “We came into the coronavirus crisis relatively defensive but the oil price came as a surprise,” Kronfol said. “At the depth of the crash, we shifted around 20% of the portfolio, with a strong bias towards sovereigns.”
column11: Oil prices have tumbled on the back of the COVID-19 pandemic as well as oversupply, worsened by the collapse last month of an agreement between OPEC and allies led by Russia. On Sunday, they agreed a new output curb deal but it has done little to lift oil prices.
column12: Franklin Templeton increased its exposure to Oman by 7% and Bahrain and Saudi Arabia by 3% each since mid-March, he said.
column13: “At the depth of the crisis, we shifted slightly down from higher-quality names into higher-yielding names. For example, selling some Abu Dhabi to buy some Saudi or to be able to buy Oman and Bahrain,” Kronfol said.
column14: He said given where Bahrain and Oman’s debt was trading, investors were expecting them to restructure within two years, which he saw as too simplistic. Kronfol expects decisive action from both countries on spending, for them to have enough resources to navigate the next two years, the Gulf states to express support for Oman and oil to recover.
column15: The yield on Bahrain’s 30-year bonds due in 2047 rose to a peak of 10% on March 20 from about 6% at end-February. Oman’s similar bonds due in 2048 rose to a peak of 12.1% yield from 7% in the same period. They have since recovered to 8% and 10% respectively.
column16: “The GCC Bond Fund was at about $205 million before this crisis and is now closer to $165 million,” he said, with about half lost due to the market and half due to redemptions.
column17: Kronfol expected Gulf assets under management to rise and said outlook for business remained positive for the year.

column4: IN BRIEF: Willkie advises Franklin Resources on $4.5 bln deal to buy Legg Mason
column5: Willkie Farr & Gallagher attorneys counseled Franklin Resources Inc, which does business as Franklin Templeton, on its agreement to buy mutual fund company Legg Mason Inc for $4.5 billion, a deal that will create an investing giant with about $1.5 trillion in assets under management, the asset manager said in a statement on Tuesday.
column6: That legal team was led by corporate and financial services partners Laura Acker and David Boston, who is co-chair of Willkie’s mergers and acquisitions practice group, and executive compensation and employee benefits group co-chair and partner Jordan Messinger, all based in New York, the law firm said Tuesday.
column7: To read the full story on WestlawNext Practitioner Insights, click here: bit.ly/2V3vp8M

column4: UPDATE 3-Franklin Resources to buy Legg Mason in union of active management 'believers'
column5: (Adds CEO comments on goals and deal origins, bylines)
column6: Feb 18 (Reuters) - Asset manager Franklin Resources Inc said on Tuesday it would buy rival Legg Mason Inc in a $4.5 billion deal as the two firms known for their stockpicking grapple with investors’ embrace of low-cost index tracking funds.
column7: The combined company would manage about $1.5 trillion in assets, making it the sixth-largest independent fund firm, according to an investor presentation on the deal. It will still trail passive giants including BlackRock Inc with $7.4 trillion under management and Vanguard Group with $5.6 trillion.
column8: In an interview Franklin Chief Executive Jenny Johnson said the deal was not driven by synergies but rather by goals like bringing in new investors especially in foreign markets, gaining scale for technology investments, and finding new ways to market and sell each others’ various fund lines.
column9: “We are firm believers in active management,” Johnson said.
column10: She said passive funds have benefited from a long bull market but have not been fully tested. In contrast the deal announced Tuesday will create what Johnson called an “all-weather lineup.”
column11: The transaction is expected to help cut Franklin's costs by about $200 million annually and would boost its adjusted earnings by more than a fifth in 2021, the companies said reut.rs/38EcJAv in a statement.
column12: Shares of Franklin were up 6% in midday trading on Tuesday, while those of Legg Mason were up 24%.
column13: Johnson is a member of the family that owns around 45% of Franklin, based in San Mateo, California, and operating as Franklin Templeton. Legg Mason of Baltimore disclosed having 3,246 employees as of May 2019, in its most recent annual report.
column14: Legg Mason’s Joseph Sullivan, CEO of the storied firm since 2012, said it has not been decided if he and other top managers will stay on after the deal closes, expected by the third quarter assuming Legg Mason wins approvals including from its fund shareholders.
column15: Sullivan said the idea for the merger first came from Franklin Chief Financial Officer Matthew Nicholls, previously a Citigroup investment banker, who invited Sullivan to a dinner in June.
column16: Sullivan said when he asked if the dinner might lead to some kind of deal talk, Nicholls was “appropriately evasive.”
column17: Tuesday’s deal was only the latest by asset managers in the consolidating industry.
column18: Federated Investors in 2018 took a majority stake in Hermes Fund Managers in 2018, and the year before Henderson Global Investors bought Janus Capital to form Janus Henderson Group PLC.
column19: Franklin’s offer of $50 per share represents a premium of 23% to Legg Mason’s Friday close. The offer also calls for Franklin to assume about $2 billion in Legg Mason’s outstanding debt.
column20: Legg Mason’s move to sell itself follows activist investor Trian Fund Management securing two seats on the company’s board in May 2019. The deal has been unanimously approved by both companies’ boards.
column21: Broadhaven Capital Partners and Morgan Stanley acted as financial advisers to Franklin Resources, while PJT Partners and J.P. Morgan Securities advised Legg Mason. (Reporting by Bharath Manjesh and C Nivedita in Bengaluru, and by Ross Kerber in Boston. Editing by Vinay Dwivedi and Tom Brown)

column4: Franklin Resources to buy Legg Mason in a $4.5 billion deal
column5: Feb 18 (Reuters) - Asset manager Franklin Resources Inc said on Tuesday it would buy mutual fund company Legg Mason Inc in an all-cash deal valued at $4.5 billion, including debt.
column6: Franklin Resources’ offer of $50 per share represents a premium of 23% to Legg Mason’s Friday close. (Reporting by Bharath Manjesh and C Nivedita in Bengaluru; Editing by Vinay Dwivedi)

column4: BlackRock, Franklin Templeton eye partnership with Banco do Brasil's asset management unit: report
column5: SAO PAULO (Reuters) - Asset managers BlackRock Inc., Franklin Templeton and Principal Financial Group are vying for a partnership with state-controlled lender Banco do Brasil’s asset management unit, a Brazilian newspaper reported on Friday.
column6: Financial adviser Rothschild & Co has the mandate to look for a partner on Friday, according the report, without saying how it obtained the information.
column7: BlackRock and Franklin Templeton did not immediately reply to requests for comment. Principal Financial and Banco do Brasil declined to comment.
column8: The asset management unit, Banco do Brasil DTVM, manages 1 trillion reais ($239.09 billion).
column9: The state-controlled bank would now select one of the three groups for exclusive talks, the report added.
column10: In November, Banco do Brasil announced a joint venture with UBS Group AG UBSG.S in investment banking, in which the Swiss bank has a controlling stake.

column4: BlackRock, Franklin Templeton eye partnership with Banco do Brasil's asset management unit - report
column5: SAO PAULO, Jan 24 (Reuters) - Asset managers BlackRock Inc., Franklin Templeton and Principal Financial Group are vying for a partnership with state-controlled lender Banco do Brasil’s asset management unit, a Brazilian newspaper reported on Friday.
column6: Financial advisor Rothschild & Co has the mandate to look for a partner on Friday, according the report, without saying how it got the information.
column7: BlackRock, Franklin Templeton and Principal Financial did not immediately comment on the matter. Banco do Brasil declined to comment.
column8: The asset management unit, Banco do Brasil DTVM, manages 1 trillion reais ($239.09 billion).
column9: The state-controlled bank would now select one of the three groups for exclusive talks, the report added.
column10: In November, Banco do Brasil announced a joint venture with UBS Group AG in investment banking, in which the Swiss bank has a controlling stake. ($1 = 4.1826 reais) (Reporting by Carolina Mandl and Tatiana Bautzer; editing by Nick Macfie)

column4: Argentine local bonds tumble ahead of index removal, Templeton may face losses
column5: NEW YORK, Nov 28 (Reuters) - A trio of Argentine peso bonds have crashed sharply in price ahead of their scheduled removal from a key index, underscoring the fragility of the country’s debt and possibly dealing major holder Franklin Templeton a loss of over half a billion dollars.
column6: Three Argentine peso bonds maturing in 2021, 2023 and 2026 have dropped between 23% and 65% from their price at the end of last month, just after Franklin Templeton raised its exposure to each of them by close to 50%.
column7: The bonds are scheduled to be removed from JPMorgan’s GBI-EM Global and Narrow series on Friday after capital controls imposed by president Mauricio Macri’s administration in September deemed them ineligible.
column8: The October 2021 bond dropped from 38.5 cents on Oct. 31 to 25.6 cents last week, before recovering slightly to 29.5 cents on Wednesday The October 2023 tumbled from 76 cents at the end of last month to 26 cents on Wednesday, according to Refinitiv data.
column9: The October 2026 hit 26.25 cents Wednesday, from over 70 cents in early October and 35 cents as of Oct. 31.
column10: According to the price drops and Franklin Templeton’s holdings as of Oct. 31, the declines amount to a paper loss of roughly $620 million across the large investor’s funds, according to a Reuters calculation.
column11: All of the firm’s funds holding these bonds are managed or co-managed by Michael Hasenstab, who oversees several bond investment strategies and made his name with contrarian bets on unloved markets that yielded huge payouts.
column12: The calculated paper losses in the Argentine bonds could be smaller if the funds exited their positions after Oct. 31, or a hedging strategy could be in place to soften the blow. Through its public relations firm, Franklin Templeton declined to comment.
column13: The three bonds were put on a watch list back in September, when JPMorgan said their removal from the GBI-EM index series would depend on whether capital controls would remain in place by the end of the review period, which ends on Friday.
column14: About $226 billion in assets is benchmarked to the GBI-EM suite of indices, JPMorgan said, based on a client survey.
column15: Argentina, gearing up for a new president in December, is locked in knife edge restructuring talks with international creditors over around $100 billion in debt amid fears over a default.
column16: Investors in Argentina have said that the local currency debt is the most vulnerable to sharp declines, since they can be written down by the government with the stroke of a pen.
column17: Since center-left candidate Alberto Fernandez’s win in the August primary election Argentine assets have continued to crumble. The peso has lost nearly 25% of its value versus the dollar and the main stock index fell almost 50% before halving that decline.
column18: Fernandez will be sworn in as president in two weeks.

column4: Franklin Templeton's K2 expands in Europe with new fund range
column5: LONDON (Reuters) - Asset manager Franklin Templeton said its K2 Advisors hedge fund investing business has expanded in Europe with the launch of a new fund range in Luxembourg to give local investors access to U.S.-based managers.
column6: K2’s platform allows investors to build a portfolio of investments across multiple funds at discounted rates. The new funds allow clients to get their money back on a daily basis rather than quarterly.
column7: The fund range will have strategies from five managers - Bardin Hill Investment Partners, Chilton Investment Company, Electron Capital Partners, Ellington Management Group and Wellington Management - Franklin said in a statement.
column8: Bill Santos, Senior Managing Director at K2 Advisors, said it would look to expand the range of managers and funds on offer and had seen strong demand from clients in Italy, Germany, Spain and elsewhere in the region to invest.
column9: K2 currently manages $10.6 billion in assets on behalf of institutional and retail clients, with around 60% of its assets managed for institutional investors using its platform.
column10: In return for reduced management fees of between 1% and 1.5% and performance fees of between 12.5% to 15%, Santos said K2 aimed to ensure each manager attracted at least $1 billion in fresh assets under management.
column11: Many hedge funds have struggled to outperform during a decade of easy money from central banks, prompting some investors to pull their cash and a number of funds to close, but more aspiring managers continue to try their luck.
column12: Data from industry tracker Hedge Fund Research said 289 funds were launched in the first half of the year, although that was outnumbered by the 399 funds that shut down.
column13: The estimated average management fee for newly launched funds in the second quarter was 1.25%, HFR said, while the average performance fee was 15.65%.
column14: (This story has been refiled as the Company corrects spelling of Bardin Hill, paragraph 3)

column4: Franklin Templeton appoints head of institutional sales, EMEA
column5: (Reuters) - Investment manager Franklin Templeton on Tuesday appointed Matthew Williams to the newly created role of senior director and head of institutional sales, EMEA.
column6: Williams joined the company in April 2013 as head of defined contribution and was later appointed as head of institutional and client service for Canada.
column7: He will be relocating to Frankfurt, Germany from Canada on Sept. 1 and will report to Vivek Kudva, managing director for EMEA and India.

column4: Franklin Templeton's Zahn buys British gilts as no-deal Brexit risk rises
column5: LONDON, June 13 (Reuters) - Franklin Templeton’s head of European fixed income David Zahn said on Thursday he had bought safe-haven UK government bonds as the chance of a no-deal Brexit rises.
column6: “We feel the chances of a no-deal Brexit are increasing,” he said.
column7: “This is in combination with the European economy not doing well and the chances of a Fed rate cut rising,” he added referring to the U.S. Federal Reserve.
column8: He said he had previously held a short position in British gilts .
column9: Zahn also said he had added “significantly” to positions in 30-year German government bonds because the European economy had not recovered as quickly as anticipated.
column10: While a rate cut from the European Central Bank was unlikely, Zahn said he expected a return to quantitative easing in 2020. (Reporting by Virginia Furness and Dhara Ranasinghe Editing by Tommy Wilkes)

column4: Franklin Templeton invests in Brazilian-Israeli fintech Weel
column5: SAO PAULO (Reuters) - Franklin Templeton has invested $30 million in Brazilian-Israeli fintech Weel as part of the U.S. asset manager’s strategy to increase its footprint in Brazil and the rest of Latin America, according a statement on Thursday.
column6: Weel, backed by venture capital investors such as Monashees and Mindset Ventures and with operations in Brazil, lends money to small-business clients by anticipating their receivables.
column7: As a partner of Weel, which uses artificial intelligence and data analysis to offer online loans at lower interest rates than traditional banks, Franklin Templeton intends to help it create more products for small companies.
column8: In addition to expanding its business in Brazil, Weel plans to start operating in Mexico and Chile by December.
column9: Weel was founded by two Brazilian residents of Israel, Simcha Neumark and Shmuel Kalmus, and one American, Russell Weiss. It will use the proceeds to serve more clients and improve technology tools.

column4: Franklin Templeton's Zahn says 30 percent probability of no-deal Brexit, may rise further
column5: LONDON (Reuters) - There is a 30 percent chance of Britain crashing out of the European Union without a divorce deal in place, Franklin Templeton’s head of European fixed income, David Zahn, said on Friday.
column6: He said the short extension offered by the EU to Britain was unlikely to fix the differences and left a no-deal scenario on the table.
column7: “We’d estimate it has around a 30 percent possibility and without any rapid progress, that likelihood will keep increasing,” Zahn told clients.

column4: Franklin Templeton's Zahn says 30 pct probability of no-deal Brexit, may rise further
column5: LONDON, March 22 (Reuters) - There is a 30 percent chance of Britain crashing out of the European Union without a divorce deal in place, Franklin Templeton’s head of European fixed income, David Zahn, said on Friday.
column6: He said the short extension offered by the EU to Britain was unlikely to fix the differences and left a no-deal scenario on the table.
column7: “We’d estimate it has around a 30 percent possibility and without any rapid progress, that likelihood will keep increasing,” Zahn told clients. (Reporting by Sujata Rao Editing by Tommy Wilkes)

column4: Franklin Templeton, Actera eyeing Abraaj's Turkey funds: sources
column5: DUBAI/ISTANBUL (Reuters) - U.S. fund manager Franklin Templeton and Turkish private equity firm Actera are among the bidders in talks to take control of Abraaj’s Turkish assets after negotiations with other buyers faltered, two sources familiar with the deal said.
column6: Dubai-based Abraaj was the largest buyout fund in the Middle East and North Africa until it collapsed last year in the aftermath of a row with investors, including the Gates Foundation, over the use of their money in a $1 billion healthcare fund.
column7: Other potential bidders for the Turkish assets such as Turkish private equity company Turkven are out of the race, the sources told Reuters.
column8: Canada’s Brookfield Asset Management, which was seen as the frontrunner for the Abraaj’s Turkish assets, has also pulled out, the Wall Street Journal reported last month. .
column10: The Turkish assets include the $526 million Turkey Fund 1, which was raised in 2016.
column11: At that time Abraaj said it had deployed $900 million across 11 investments in Turkey over a decade.
column12: Franklin Templeton, which manages over $683 billion, did not offer any comment. Actera, which manages $3.3 billion, and Turkven did not respond to a Reuters request for comment.
column13: Abraaj’s liquidators did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment.
column14: U.S. investment group Colony Capital Inc CLNY.N has agreed to buy Abraaj's private equity business in Latin America, while TPG has taken control of its $1 billion healthcare fund. These are the only two of Abraaj's funds known to have found new managers.
column15: Actis is the front-runner for the $1 billion Abraaj Private Equity Fund IV, but it still needs to convince investors in the fund to vote for the deal, a source said last month.

column4: Franklin Templeton's bond chief says expects at least two Fed rate hikes in 2019
column5: (Reuters) - The U.S. Federal Reserve will likely raise at least twice in 2019 against a backdrop of continued economic strength as opposed to “misguided” market assumptions of no hikes this year, according to Franklin Templeton’s head of bonds.
column6: “I would still anticipate that it will deliver at least two more rate hikes this year. I believe that the market’s assumption that the Fed will not raise interest rates at all this year is very misguided, against a background of continued economic strength,” said Sonal Desai, chief investment officer for the Fixed Income Group at Franklin Templeton.
column7: She said in a note that the $750 billion fund manager’s view on China has become somewhat more pessimistic than it has been historically.
column8: “In my view, the global outlook is a bit more at risk from China today than it was say two or three years ago. This is something which we will be monitoring extremely carefully,” she said.

column4: UK appeal court backs Sberbank, Franklin Templeton on IBA debt restructuring
column5: MOSCOW, Dec 20 (Reuters) - A British court of appeal backed Russian lender Sberbank and asset manager Franklin Templeton in a ruling relating to funds owed by the International Bank of Azerbaijan (IBA), potentially scuppering the latter’s restructuring plan.
column6: In 2017, state-run IBA proposed a plan to restructure $3.3 billion of its debt and said in July it had received approval from creditors holding 93.9 percent of the affected credits.
column7: As part of the restructuring, which was done under Azeri law, IBA had obtained a moratorium from a London court, preventing creditors from taking action against it without court permission.
column8: In an initial ruling in January, a London court backed Sberbank and Franklin Templeton, which opposed the extension of this moratorium. However, IBA appealed the ruling.
column9: Neither Sberbank, the sole lender of a $20 million facility to IBA, nor Franklin Templeton, which holds some of the lender’s 2019 notes agreed to the restructuring.
column10: Both holders argued their dealings with IBA were governed by English law and in its ruling on Monday, the court of appeal backed them.
column11: “The purpose of the application, as is candidly conceded, is to prevent the English creditors from relying on their rights under English law to seek to enforce their claims against the company’s assets,” the court ruling stated.
column12: Sberbank’s vice president Maxim Degtyarev told Reuters the Russian lender would now seek to enforce payment. IBA holds a stake in IBA-Moscow which is headquartered in the Russian capital.
column13: “Now Sberbank has the right to collect the debt from IBA in full, including interest and penalties,” Degtyarev said.
column14: IBA declined to comment on the ruling. (Reporting by Tatiana Voronova in Moscow, writing by Karin Strohecker in London; Editing by Elaine Hardcastle.)

column4: Franklin Templeton grabs more Gulf corporate debt after downturn
column5: DUBAI, Dec 19 (Reuters) - Franklin Templeton Investments has raised its Gulf corporate debt exposure as a downturn in some sectors, largely real estate, has hit company valuations, Dino Kronfol, its chief investment officer of global sukuk and MENA fixed income, said.
column6: “Some independent corporates really sold off over the past few months, that’s why we say there’s more value in the weaker, higher-yielding names,” Kronfol told Reuters.
column7: Franklin Templeton, which had $683 billion in assets under management as of the end of November, has increased the exposure of its $350 million Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) bond strategy to regional corporates by roughly 20 percent this year to 72 percent, of which 10 percent was in the last quarter.
column8: “Valuations are much better than they were 12-18 months ago. Pressure in some industries has led to a sell off, and the weaker the name, the easier it is for stress to build up fairly quickly, but this creates opportunity,” Kronfol said.
column9: At the same time Franklin Templeton has cut its exposure to high-grade, mainly sovereign, credits. “We have flipped our exposure to corporates. We are underweight sovereigns while chock-full on corporate exposure,” Kronfol added.
column10: A combination of emerging markets weakness and a slump in the property and construction industries sparked by government cut backs on project spending have caused volatility across the region’s corporate debt market over the past year, with a particular spike in yields in the last three months.
column11: Yields on Islamic bonds issued by Qatar’s Ezdan due in 2022 rose by 6 percentage points this year to 13 percent. In Dubai, DAMAC’s bonds due in 2019 rose by 2.5 percentage points while bonds issued by a real estate fund, Emirates REIT, rose by 2.7 percentage points.
column12: “It’s actually good to see some dispersion of returns between countries and sectors,” Kronfol said.
column13: Franklin Templeton’s GCC strategy generated total returns of 1 percent this year, well below its last five-year average annualised rate, which was 5.5-6 percent.
column14: Kronfol said the main reason for low total returns was a rise in U.S. Treasuries over the year, although “on a relative basis the region has done very well”.
column15: He expects regional debt supply to continue to be healthy next year, with around $75 to $80 billion in total debt issues, and estimates total returns from the GCC debt market next year to be in mid-to-high single digits.
column16: And while the outlook for the real estate sector remains grim, Kronfol said that some sectors which are seeing a downturn are “actually in okay shape.” (Reporting by Davide Barbuscia Editing by Alexander Smith)

column4: Franklin Templeton taps into Israel's $67 billion retail market
column5: TEL AVIV (Reuters) - Franklin Templeton Investments entered the $67 billion Israeli retail market on Tuesday after the government allowed foreign firms to offer offshore products directly to investors.
column6: Previously, such investments had to be distributed in Israel through a local manager or bank, which increased fees and made them more expensive for Israeli investors.
column7: “Over the years, we have been witnessing Israeli investors’ increasing preference for foreign investments,” Jenny Johnson, president and chief operating officer of Franklin Templeton, said at the opening of the group’s new office in Tel Aviv.
column8: Although assets under management of domestic funds investing in foreign securities have more than doubled in the past three years to $7.7 billion, a lack of choice means they still account for only 12 percent of total assets, she said.
column9: Franklin Templeton, which has $724 billion in assets under management, appointed Uzi Yitzhak to head its business in Israel, where the firm also registered two mutual funds.
column10: Franklin Templeton executives also gave prospective Israeli investors their views on a number of markets during the opening.
column11: Manraj Sekhon, chief investment officer for emerging markets equity, said the firm would not be in a position to meaningfully increase its Turkish fund allocation while policies are in flux.
column12: Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan last month named several advisers and a theology professor to a new economic policy committee, as Ankara seeks to reassure foreign investors spooked by a falling lira currency and high inflation.
column13: Franklin Templeton has also not changed its position in Saudi Arabia following the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi at the Saudi consulate in Turkey last month. The main question, he said, is how economic reforms are implemented.
column14: Brazil, Mexico and Indonesia all offered attractive investment opportunities, Sekhon said.
column15: John Beck, director of fixed income at Franklin Templeton, said Britain’s gilt market was overvalued, while the pound “is at the cheap end of expectations”.

column4: RPT-Franklin Templeton likes Brazil, Mexico, Indonesian markets
column5: (Repeats with no changes to story)
column6: TEL AVIV, Nov 13 (Reuters) - Franklin Templeton Investments’ fixed income director said on Thursday markets in Brazil, Mexico and Indonesia were attractive investment opportunities while the UK bond market is “relatively expensive”.
column7: Speaking at the launching of the firm’s office in Israel, John Beck also said Russia was “not a significant holding in almost any of our strategies”.
column8: Manraj Sekhon, chief investment officer for emerging markets equity, said that volatility in the next 6-12 months presented an opportunity to increase allocations in emerging markets. (Reporting by Tova Cohen Editing by Steven Scheer)

column4: Franklin Templeton likes Brazil, Mexico, Indonesian markets
column5: TEL AVIV, Nov 13 (Reuters) - Franklin Templeton Investments’ fixed income director said on Thursday markets in Brazil, Mexico and Indonesia were attractive investment opportunities while the UK bond market is “relatively expensive”.
column6: Speaking at the launching of the firm’s office in Israel, John Beck also said Russia was “not a significant holding in almost any of our strategies”.
column7: Manraj Sekhon, chief investment officer for emerging markets equity, said that volatility in the next 6-12 months presented an opportunity to increase allocations in emerging markets. (Reporting by Tova Cohen Editing by Steven Scheer)

column4: MOVES-Fiduciary Trust Co appoints new senior portfolio manager
column5: Aug 3 (Reuters) - Asset manager Fiduciary Trust Co International, a unit of Franklin Templeton Investments, on Friday appointed Edgardo Gonzalez as a managing director and senior portfolio manager at its office in Coral Gables, Florida.
column6: Gonzalez, who most recently served as a portfolio manager at U.S. Trust in Fort Lauderdale, has also spent more than eight years with JPMorgan Chase & Co. (Reporting by Diptendu Lahiri in Bengaluru)

column4: MOVES-Franklin Templeton hires Walsh as portfolio manager at multi-asset solutions
column5: July 2 (Reuters) - Franklin Templeton Investments on Monday named Brendan Walsh as portfolio manager at its multi-asset solutions team to lead development of the firm’s multi-asset capabilities in the United Kingdom.
column6: Walsh most recently served as a multi-asset fund manager at Aviva Investors.
column7: Walsh, based in London, will report to the director of portfolio management at the multi-assets solutions team, Thomas Nelson. (Reporting by Manas Mishra in Bengaluru)

column4: MOVES-Franklin Templeton hires Jennifer Ockwell as head of UK Institutional
column5: June 15 (Reuters) - Franklin Templeton Investments said on Friday it has hired Jennifer Ockwell as head of UK Institutional, where she will be responsible for institutional sales and client service in the UK.
column6: Ockwell will be based in its London office and report to UK Country Head Martyn Gilbey, Franklin Templeton’s said.
column7: Previously, Ockwell headed the UK Institutional at global asset management group Janus Henderson. (Reporting by Nivedita Balu in Bengaluru; Editing by Gopakumar Warrier)

column4: Franklin Templeton's Zahn says ECB rate rise unlikely before 2020
column5: LONDON, June 5 (Reuters) - Recent weak economic data and turbulence in Italy point towards an extension of the European Central Bank’s stimulus scheme, with an interest rate hike unlikely before 2020, Franklin Templeton’s head of European fixed income said on Tuesday.
column6: ECB policy makers gather next week in a meeting that is likely to be scrutinized closely for clues on the ECB’s timetable for scaling back asset purchases - currently scheduled to end in September.
column7: In a note, Franklin Templeton’s David Zahn said he expected the ECB to extend stimulus at least to the end of this year and most likely into 2019.
column8: “The recent flare-up in Italy only reinforces our view that the ECB will extend the asset-buying programme into 2019. And, we think the likelihood of rate hikes is now pushed out much further into the future,” Zahn said.
column9: He added that it was “difficult to see” interest rate hikes in the euro zone before 2020.
column10: Current money market pricing suggests investors anticipate a ECB rate rise by September next year. (Reporting by Dhara Ranasinghe; editing by Sujata Rao)

column4: BRIEF-Franklin Resources Inc Reports 13.3 Percent Passive Stake In Talos Energy Inc As Of May 10
column5: May 16 (Reuters) - Talos Energy Inc:
column6: * FRANKLIN RESOURCES INC REPORTS 13.3 PERCENT PASSIVE STAKE IN TALOS ENERGY INC AS OF MAY 10, 2018 - SEC FILING Source text - bit.ly/2IqznTV Further company coverage:

column4: BRIEF-Franklin Resources Announces Month-End Assets Under Management
column5: May 8 (Reuters) - Franklin Resources Inc:
column6: * FRANKLIN RESOURCES, INC. ANNOUNCES MONTH-END ASSETS UNDER MANAGEMENT
column7: * FRANKLIN RESOURCES INC - PRELIMINARY MONTH-END ASSETS UNDER MANAGEMENT OF $732.5 BILLION AT APRIL 30, 2018, COMPARED TO $737.5 BILLION AT MARCH 31, 2018
column8: * FRANKLIN RESOURCES INC - PRELIMINARY AVERAGE ASSETS UNDER MANAGEMENT FOR QUARTER, THROUGH APRIL 30, 2018, WERE $735.0 BILLION Source text for Eikon: Further company coverage:

column4: BRIEF-Franklin Templeton Investments Canada Not To Proceed With Proposed Changes To Franklin Bissett Dividend Income Funds

column4: Malaysia should look beyond ringgit to draw Chinese to sukuk market - Franklin Templeton
column5: KUALA LUMPUR, April 25 (Reuters) - Malaysia’s Islamic bond market could attract Chinese companies if there were more foreign currency-denominated issues, a chief investment officer at fund manager Franklin Templeton Investments said on Wednesday.
column6: Malaysia is one of the largest markets for Islamic finance, which follows religious principles such as bans on interest and monetary speculation.
column7: Chief investment officer for global sukuk and MENA fixed income, Mohieddine Kronfol, said some Chinese companies are coming into the sukuk market and Malaysia was well positioned to benefit, but it would need to go beyond ringgit-denominated issuances.
column8: “The policy makers have expressed interest to make Malaysia a hub for Islamic finance and to a certain extent it’s very difficult to do that if everything is denominated in the local currency,” he said.
column9: “That segment is something that I feel like Malaysia could play a role in, in trying to attract Chinese companies. But to really be able to (do that), it has to be not just (fundraising) in Malaysia but internationally,” he said in a group interview on Wednesday.
column10: He said Malaysia has attracted foreign companies to issue sukuk, but they were predominantly in ringgit and largely domestically bought.
column11: Mohieddine said there should be more transactions in international currencies like the U.S. dollar, and a currency regime or some central bank support that facilitates that.
column12: “If you want to have a more global role, you need to be able to cater to demand that’s outside of Malaysia,” he said.
column13: “That happens when the currency is a little more freely convertible and when you have issues in different currencies.”
column14: Mohieddine said the Chinese interest in sukuk is nascent but the appetite for sukuk would likely start with big issuers like Chinese real estate and financial services companies.
column15: “If the sukuk market remains healthy and policy makers take steps to make the Malaysian market more international, and the Chinese look to diversify their source of funding ... (it’s) feasible, arguably, to happen in the next few years,” he said.
column16: Franklin Templeton Investments projects global sukuk growth at 15-20 percent this year on the back of stable oil prices, better growth outlook in markets that issue sukuks and sustained demand for Islamic finance. (Reporting by Liz Lee; Editing by Elaine Hardcastle)
